thread.title: Emboldened Israel government OKs 3,000 new settlement homes
thread.title_full: Emboldened Israel government OKs 3,000 new settlement homes

author: cbc
title: Emboldened Israel government OKs 3,000 new settlement homes
text:
Israel has announced plans to build 3,000 new homes in West Bank settlements, pressing forward with a construction binge that began after the inauguration of Donald Trump as U.S. president.
The announcement comes as Israel prepares to uproot an illegal settlement outpost in the West Bank. It appears to be aimed at calming settler anger over the impending court-ordered evacuation of the Amona outpost.
Israeli teens walk on graffiti reading 'Soldier, policeman, refuse orders' on Dec. 9, 2016. The move to create more settlements is seen as retaliation over an impending court-ordered evacuation of a Jewish settlement called Amona, also in the West Bank. (Amir Cohen/Reuters)
In a late-night statement Tuesday, Israel's defence ministry said the latest construction was approved by Defence Minister Avigdor Lieberman and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu. It comes days after the government approved an additional 2,500 homes in the West Bank and hundreds more in east Jerusalem.
The Palestinians and the international community consider authorized settlements and outposts illegal or illegitimate, and an obstacle to the peace process. The Palestinians want the West Bank, along with the Gaza Strip and east Jerusalem, for their future state. Israel captured the three territories in the 1967 Mideast war.
About half a million Israelis live in settlements, including Ma'ale Adumim, in the West Bank. (Reuters)

The election of Donald Trump, who has promised to be far more supportive of Israel than his predecessor, has emboldened Israel's settlement movement.
Israel approves 2,500 new West Bank settlement homes Netanyahu to meet with Trump before calling vote on West Bank annexation His campaign platform made no mention of a Palestinian state, a cornerstone of two decades of international diplomacy in the region, and he has signalled that he will be far more tolerant of Israeli settlement construction.
Obama talks about Israel, Syria and Trump in his final interview as president
